Award.AwardTitle: Problems of Geophysical Fluid Mechanics: Modeling, Theory and Computing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will address problems in mathematical ocean and atmosphere sciences, related to weather and climate prediction. Two classes of problems will be investigated. The first one is that of the boundary conditions for limited area weather models for which physical models do not provide natural boundary conditions. This problem is as old as numerical weather prediction itself, and it is expected that inappropriate boundary conditions will introduce spurious modes, in particular as improved computing capabilities allow better spatial and temporal resolutions. The aim is to derive boundary conditions that lead to mathematically correct problems, and that are computationally satisfactory in the sense that they let the waves move freely inside and outside the domain of computation. The PI will continue his investigations in this direction. The second class of problems is that of moist convection, precipitations and clouds. Our limited understanding of the physics of clouds is one of the primary causes of uncertainty in the current weather and climate predictions. The difficulties are in part due to the large differences in scales, ranging from cloud sizes of hundreds of kilometers to particles (droplets of water, ice or aerosols) of a few microns. There is a similar range of time scales. The project will study this physical problem using mathematical tools from convex analysis and variational inequalities. Numerical multilevel methods will be used as well to study the interaction of clouds and topography near the equator; and finally the tools of convex analysis will also be used for the very modeling of the changes of phase in the clouds. These studies will be conducted in close collaboration with physicists. The project will involve graduate students and post-doctoral associates who will be trained in this important interdisciplinary area.

This research project will study fundamental problems in the numerical prediction of weather and climate, as well as problems in the mathematical modeling of clouds and evaporation. The project component related to numerical weather prediction addresses the problem of using information from coarse featured global weather data for fine grained local and regional predictions. If the coarse data are not coupled correctly to the regional model that has higher resolution, then spurious systematic errors (e.g. "ghost" weather fronts) may arise. The project will investigate the mathematical foundations of this problem. The project component on the modeling of clouds and evaporation will use advanced mathematical tools to contribute to the understanding of a set of basic open problems in weather and climate research: Do clouds help cool the planet (because they reflect sunlight) or do they contribute to warming (because they can hold thermal energy)? Weather prediction and climate modeling are objectives with important human, social and economic interest. The project will also train young scientists at the interface of mathematics, geophysical fluid mechanics, and scientific computing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

 Many numerical simulations for weather and climate predictions for e.g. agricultural, social, or transportation applications are made on limited domains which are somehow arbitrarily chosen. An important issue is then the choice of the boundary conditions which are needed for the solution of the partial differential equations governing the physical data, such as temperatures or velocity of wind. The boundary conditions must be non-reflective and allow the waves to enter or exit the domain freely. For example, imposing at the boundary of the domain a boundary condition which amounts to inserting a wall will produce reflection of waves within the domain and affect the numerical solutions. There are no physical laws providing boundary conditions at the boundary of a non-physical domain, and choosing suitable boundary conditions depends on the computational, physical and mathematical analysis of the problems. It is believed that this problem will need new methods in view of the future calculations with high performance computers. During the period of this award we have found the appropriate boundary conditions in a number of situations for the linear and non-linear inviscid shallow water equations, which are also single modes of the primitive equations.

Another major problem in geophysical sciences is the study of the humid atmosphere with saturation. A phenomena as common as the clouds is nevertheless far to be understood from the physical point of view and the specialists believe that the clouds (and the aerosols participating in their formation and evolution) are the greatest source of uncertainty regarding the current numerical simulations. The clouds play a major role in the energetic balance of the Earth. Through a variety of physical processes like radiative and thermic processes, fusion enthalpies, vaporization, latent heat, the clouds affect the small vertical convective structures which transport heat and humidity, and the large global structures which carry the heat from the tropics to the great latitudes, and the other structures such as the monsoon and El Niño.

The clouds are a multi-scale phenomenon. The clouds of size hundreds to thousands of kilometers are made of very small particles of water in liquid or solid phase (ice), and of natural aerosols like sands or volcanic ashes or anthropogenic aerosols (pollution) with sizes of a few tenths of a micrometer. Hence, about 3 scales in times and 14 scales in space are necessary for a good description of the clouds, which is far beyond our current computing power.

Because of their physical and computational complexity, a full understanding of these multiscale phenomena are beyond our current abilities and some simplified descriptions called “parameterization" are necessary, which are based in part on statistical estimations.

For a better description of clouds in the future, it will be necessary to use the full equations describing the evolution of each of its components (air, water vapor, liquid water, ice, pollutants, etc.). Because of the changes of phase, these equations are discontinuous nonlinear partial differential equations, a subject challenging for mathematicians, modelers and computer scientists.

During the time of this award we have initiated the study of the equations of the humid atmosphere with saturation, which has never been made before. The equations are those of the velocity of the wind, the temperature of the air, and the content of water vapor in the air. As we said these equations are non-linear, and non-continuous. We have introduced a formulation of the humid atmosphere with saturation and proved the existence, uniqueness and regularity of solutions for this model.
